Line 2: Line 2:
A '''puppy mill''', sometimes known as a '''puppy farm''',<ref>[http://montereycountydemocrats.org/node/621 Farr Introduces Bill to Regulate Puppy Farms]</ref> is a commercial [[dog breeding]] facility that is operated with an emphasis upon profits above animal welfare and is often in substandard conditions regarding the well-being of dogs in their care.<ref name="aspca_puppy_mills">{{cite web |url=http://www.aspca.org/site/PageServer?pagename=cruelty_puppymills |accessdate=2007-12-13 |year=2007 |author=ASPCA |title=Fight Animal Cruelty: Puppy Mills}}</ref><ref name="redeye_20071119">{{cite news |url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CREB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=11D0B2F033A603F0&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated4&req_dat=AA98CDC331574F0ABEAFF732B33DC0B2 |title=Buy or adopt? Where you get your pet is a big decisionâand a big controversy |author=Swartz, Tracy |publisher=Chicago Tribune RedEye Edition |date=2007-11-19}}</ref> Similar types of operations exist for other animals commonly kept as pets or used as feed for other animals.
A '''puppy mill''', sometimes known as a '''puppy farm''',<ref>[http://montereycountydemocrats.org/node/621 Farr Introduces Bill to Regulate Puppy Farms]</ref> is a commercial [[dog breeding]] facility that is operated with an emphasis upon profits above animal welfare and is often in substandard conditions regarding the well-being of dogs in their care.<ref name="aspca_puppy_mills">{{cite web |url=http://www.aspca.org/site/PageServer?pagename=cruelty_puppymills |accessdate=2007-12-13 |year=2007 |author=ASPCA |title=Fight Animal Cruelty: Puppy Mills}}</ref><ref name="redeye_20071119">{{cite news |url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CREB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=11D0B2F033A603F0&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated4&req_dat=AA98CDC331574F0ABEAFF732B33DC0B2 |title=Buy or adopt? Where you get your pet is a big decisionâand a big controversy |author=Swartz, Tracy |publisher=Chicago Tribune RedEye Edition |date=2007-11-19}}</ref> Similar types of operations exist for other animals commonly kept as pets or used as feed for other animals.
The term can be applied to operations involving other animals commercially bred for profit, e.g. "kitty mills."<ref name="aspca_glossary">{{cite web |url=http://www.aspca.org/site/PageServer?pagename=cruelty_crueltyglossary |title=ASPCA: Fight Animal Cruelty: Cruelty Glossary |author=ASPCA |year=2007 |accessdate=2007-12-13}}</ref> There are an estimated 4,000 puppy mills in the U.S. that produce more than half a million puppies a year.<ref name="mlb.ilstu.edu">http://www.mlb.ilstu.edu/cgi-bin/redirect.cgi?http://wf2dnvr8.webfeat.org:80/bOMzK1961/url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=hxh&AN=14054225&loginpage=Login.asp&site=ehost-live&scope=site</ref> Commercial kennels may be licensed by the United States Department of Agriculture which may inspect the kennels routinely.<ref>[http://www.aphis.usda.gov/publications/animal_welfare/content/printable_version/faq_animal_dealers.pdf Questions and Answers on Animal Careâs Regulation of Commercial Animal Dealers]</ref>
The term can be applied to operations involving other animals commercially bred for profit, e.g. "kitty mills."<ref name="aspca_glossary">{{cite web |url=http://www.aspca.org/site/PageServer?pagename=cruelty_crueltyglossary |title=ASPCA: Fight Animal Cruelty: Cruelty Glossary |author=ASPCA |year=2007 |accessdate=2007-12-13}}</ref> There are an estimated 4,000 puppy mills in the U.S. that produce more than half a million puppies a year.<ref name="mlb.ilstu.edu">http://www.mlb.ilstu.edu/cgi-bin/redirect.cgi?http://wf2dnvr8.webfeat.org:80/bOMzK1961/url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=hxh&AN=14054225&loginpage=Login.asp&site=ehost-live&scope=site</ref> Commercial kennels may be licensed by the United States Department of Agriculture which may inspect the kennels routinely.<ref>[http://www.aphis.usda.gov/publications/animal_welfare/content/printable_version/faq_animal_dealers.pdf Questions and Answers on Animal Careâs Regulation of Commercial Animal Dealers]</ref>
â   â   â
Many stores that sell dogs usually get their dogs from puppy mills. Puppy mills are very inhumane, and usually psycologically damage a dog.
  â   â
'''ways to know if your dog is from a puppy mill:'''
  â   â
Is you dog skiddish?
  â   â
If you got your dog from a breeder, did you meet on neutral ground, such as a park?
  â   â
Is your dog frightened easily?
  â   â
Was your dog sick (vomiting and diherriah included) when you first brought him/her home?
  â  
For-profit breeding on a smaller scale is sometimes referred to as '''backyard breeding'''.<ref name="aspca_glossary" />
For-profit breeding on a smaller scale is sometimes referred to as '''backyard breeding'''.<ref name="aspca_glossary" />
